description: Estimated fishery access for boat based and land based fishing based on boat ramps, shoreline access, roads, and steepness of shoreline.
Marine Recreational Fishery Survey (hmrfs) data on the percent of households that fish. This information is used to estimate the need per county.
The number of residents per county. The number of residents and the need is used to get a percentage of the total residents that fish.
The resource was calculated as the total available harvest fish biomass compared to pristine fish biomass.
The area of current fishponds per county.
Ocean acidification pressure scaled using biological thresholds.
The estimated pressure on the nearshore and coastal areas from sea level rise.
Sea surface temperature anomalies.
The modeled UV radiation based on Erythemal UV Irradiance data provided by GES DISC.

The estimated pressure caused on the nearshore environment due to ocean warming. The maximum observed Degree Heating Week (DHW) per pixel was calculated over the time frame of the data (2013-2016). Pixels exceeding 12 DHW were set to the maximum value since it is likely that major coral mortality has occurred those areas.
The number of potential Community Based Subsistence Fishing Areas (CBSFA) and interested communities, and the active fishponds, scaled to maximum number per county.
The condition of coastal habitats measured as the percent of beaches erroding per region.
reference: Fletcher, C.H., Romine, B.M., Genz, A.S., Barbee, M.M., Dyer, Matthew, Anderson, T.R., Lim, S.C., Vitousek, Sean, Bochicchio, Christopher, and Richmond, B.M., 2012, National assessment of shoreline change: Historical shoreline change in the Hawaiian Islands: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2011–1051, 55 p.

description: The condition of coastal wetlands measured as the percent of historic extent.
reference: Van Rees, CB and Reed M (2014) Wetland loss in Hawaii since human settlement. Wetlands 34:335-350

description: The benthic condition of coral reefs assessed through a combination of variables including percent coral cover, percent macroalgae cover, demography, and mortality.
Beach extent was caluclated from the from ESI GIS layer (Beaches (3,4,5 classifications)). The data units are in km not km2 like other habitats.
The average short-term errosine rate of beaches, estimated at -0.06 m per year.
reference: Fletcher, C.H., Romine, B.M., Genz, A.S., Barbee, M.M., Dyer, Matthew, Anderson, T.R., Lim, S.C., Vitousek, Sean, Bochicchio, Christopher, and Richmond, B.M., 2012, National assessment of shoreline change: Historical shoreline change in the Hawaiian Islands: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2011–1051, 55 p.

description: The area of coastal wetlands (within 1 km of the coastline).
Hardbottom extent out to 80 meters modified from NOAA habitat maps.
reference: Lecky 2016 Ecosystem vulnerability and mapping cumulative impacts on Hawaiian reefs

description: The annual percent change in wetland extend based on NOAA C-CAP data comparisions from 2005 to 2010/2011.
The estimated change in percent coral cover calculated from the past 5 years of available monitoring data from NOAA Coral Reef Ecosystem Program.
This is a list of habitats in each region weighted by proportion of the total area for each habitat.
Coastal pelagic fish catch (lbs) reported in the commercial fishery.
Bottomfish catch (lbs) reported in the commercial fishery.
Pelagic fish catch (lbs) reported in the commercial fishery.
Reef fish catch (lbs) reported in the commercial fishery.
A multiplier for reported commercial catch of nearshore fish used to estimate the contribution of non-commercial (recreation & subsistence) catch.
Bottomfish stock assessment.
Pelagic (tuna and swordfish) stock assessments.
reference: International Scientific Committee for Tuna and Tuna-like Species in the North Pacific Ocean (ISC)

description: Reef fish stock assessment.
The percent of native forests dominated by non-native species.

header_layer: percent of forest dominated by non-native species
description: The percent of forest dominated by non-native species.
The ratio of catch to bycatch for the tuna fishery (deep set longlines).
reference: NOAA bycatch summary report for Pacific Islands

description: The ratio of catch to bycatch for swordfish fishery (shallow set longlines).
reference: NOAA bycatch summary report for Pacific Islands

description: The pressure on the nearshore from aquarium fishing estimated as the reported take to DAR.

header_layer: management and protection of habitat to preserve biodiversity (fisheries)
description: The survey responses by country to the Convention on Biologicial Diversity (CBD) Third National Report: habitat related questions.
The estimated management effectiveness of regulations and management of commercial fishing.

header_layer: artisanal fisheries management effectiveness and opportunity
description: The opportunity for artisanal and recreational fishing based on the quality of management of the small-scale fishing sector.
The ratio of management areas to total coastal area within 3nm.
reference: NOAA MPA spatial data layer (management areas include no take, multiple use, national parks, and santucary waters

header_layer: EEZ protected marine areas to protect fishery resources
description: The protected marine areas within the EEZ to protect fishery resources.
reference: goal scores for Lasting Special Places

description: The ratio of management areas (BRFA, Longline, Monument) to the total ocean area with the EEZ and divided into OHI regions.
reference: NOAA MPA spatial data layer (management areas include no take, multiple use, national parks, and santucary waters

description: The modeled reef fish catch from commercial and recreational fishery taking into account shoreline accessibility.
The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) signatories.
The inflation adjusted usd.
Beach extent was caluclated from the from ESI GIS layer (Beaches (3,4,5 classifications)). The data units are in km not km2 like other habitats.
The eetlands extent layer was created from HI wetlands layer (1979) and TNC marxan wetlands layer. Deep water habitats were removed to focus on nearshore estuaries and wetlands.
reference: HI wetlands layer (1979) and TNC marxan wetlands layer.

description: The hardbottom extent out to 80 meters modified from NOAA habitat maps.
reference: Lecky 2016 Ecosystem vulnerability and mapping cumulative impacts on Hawaiian reefs

description: Soft bottom habitat extent was derived from the cumulative impact habitat maps.
reference: Lecky 2016 Ecosystem vulnerability and mapping cumulative impacts on Hawaiian reefs

description: The condition of coastal habitats measured as the percent of beaches erroding per region.
Wetland condition was calculated based on percent of historical extent.
reference: Van Rees, CB and Reed M (2014) Wetland loss in Hawaii since human settlement. Wetlands 34:335-350

description: The benthic condition of coral reefs assessed through a combination of variables including percent coral cover, percent macroalgae cover, demography, and mortality.
The percent of softbottom habitat not impacted by dredging.
reference: Lecky 2016 Ecosystem vulnerability and mapping cumulative impacts on Hawaiian reefs

description: The average short-term errosine rate of beaches, estimated at -0.06 m per year.
reference: Fletcher, C.H., Romine, B.M., Genz, A.S., Barbee, M.M., Dyer, Matthew, Anderson, T.R., Lim, S.C., Vitousek, Sean, Bochicchio, Christopher, and Richmond, B.M., 2012, National assessment of shoreline change: Historical shoreline change in the Hawaiian Islands: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2011–1051, 55 p. (Also available at http:// pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1051.)

description: The annual percent change in wetland extend based on NOAA C-CAP data comparisions from 2005 to 2010/2011.
The estimated change in percent coral cover calculated from the past 5 years of available monitoring data from NOAA Coral Reef Ecosystem Program.
Trend was not evaluated for soft bottom habitats.
Benthic structures were defined as manmade features in the offshore environment that disrupt benthic habitat and include moored buoys, channel markers, offshore cables and pipelines.

header_layer: habitat destruction caused by coastal engineering
description: Coastal engineering consisted of shoreline armoring structures (e.g., seawalls, revetments, groins, break waters), artificial land (i.e., land fill), and piers.
Dredging was defined as activity involving physically removing substrate with machinery typically to allow for safe passage of vessels.

The coastal population density (withing 25 mi from shore)  as a proxy for intertidal habitat destruction, calculated as resident population per km of shoreline and standardized by maximum regional score.
reference: DBEDT average resident population per county

description: The ratio of management areas to total coastal area within 3nm.
reference: NOAA MPA spatial data layer (management areas include no take, multiple use, national parks, and santucary waters

header_layer: protected marine areas within EEZ to protect against habitat destruction
description: Protected marine areas within EEZ to protect against habitat destruction.
The ratio of management areas (BRFA, Longline, Monument) to the total ocean area with the EEZ and divided into OHI regions.
reference: NOAA MPA spatial data layer (management areas include no take, multiple use, national parks, and santucary waters

description: To represent the risk of ship groundings and wrecks to coastal waters, the footprint of this ship traffic layer was clipped to 9 m depth.

header_layer: direct impacts from humans (trampling, recreation, etc)
description: InVEST recreation model was run statewide at 1 km resolution for the years 2005 - 2014. This model uses publicly visible geotagged photos posted to the photo-sharing website Flickr to calculate the annual average number of photo users per day per grid cell. This is a proxy for direct human impact to nearshore and coastal environments.
The percent of priority watersheds that are fenced to protect againts invasive animals.
The revenue generated per ocean sector for each county.
The total number of jobs per ocean sector for each county.
The number of residents per county.
The unemployment rate.
The total number of jobs per county.
The State New Economy Index uses 25 indicators to measure the extent to which state economies are knowledge-based, globalized, entrepreneurial, IT-driven, and innovation-oriented.

header_layer: competitiveness in achieving sustained economic prosperity
description: The Global Competitiveness Index (GCI) scores from the World Economic Forum.

header_layer: sector evenness as a measure of economic diversity
description: The Shannon's Diversity Index calculated sector evenness based on the total number of sectors and the proportion of jobs belonging to any sector.

header_layer: area within 1 km of the shore
description: The coastal area within 1 km of the shore.
The offshore area to 3nm.
The area and type of conservation districts within 1km of the coastline.
The conservation district type and area within 1km of the coastline.
The offshore areas protected to 3nm, including CBSFA, FRA, BFA, and MPA classifications.
The ratio of the number of current fishponds to historical fishponds.
Yield (lbs) of finfish and shellfish.
The number of mariculture operators.
The onsite waste disposal systems (ODSD) as proxy of nitrogen flux to the nearshore water.

header_layer: land-based sediment export to nearshore water
description: The pressure on the nearshore from sedimentation. Falinski (2016) customized, parameterized, calibrated, and ran the Integrated Valuation of Ecosystem Services and Tradeoffs (InVEST) model for sediment delivery for each of the eight Main Hawaiian Islands. This model predicts the average annual amount of sediment (tons/yr) exported from each map pixel as a function of land use/land cover, soil characteristics, rainfall, slope, geology, and hydrology.

header_layer: land-based source of pollution from agriculture and golf courses
description: The proxy for agricultural and landscaping runoff (nutrients from fertilizers; chemicals like pesticides and herbicides), calculated as the area of agricultural land and golf courses by watershed.

header_layer: land-based source of pollution from urban runoff
description: A proxy for nutrient and chemical pollution.
The State of Hawaii Division of Aquatic Resources aerial imagery of marine debris from 2015.
Ship traffic layer was used as a proxy for ship-based pollution.
The NOAA Coral Reef Conservation Program 2014 socioeconomic surveys of human use, knowledge, attitudes, and perceptions in Hawaii.
The scores from the habitats subgoal of biodiversity are used as resilience for Livelihoods and Economies and the Sustainable Tourism goals.
The Social Progress Index scores.
The survey responses by country to the Convention on Biologicial Diversity (CBD) Third National Report: invasive species related questions.
The environmental footprint of terrestrial aquaculture facilities.
Represents presence-only of invasive algae species in nearshore waters and mangroves along the shoreline.

header_layer: Mo'omeheu - Value of History and Culture
description: The preservation of culture. Mo'omeheu - Value of History and Culture.
The Species subgoal scores calculated within 3 nm of shoreline as a proxy for ecological integrity.
The calculated fish biomass score in relation to pristine biomass from the NOAA report card.
The list of Hawaii coastal plant species and status of coastal sand-dune plants scored based on ESA status.
The list of marine mammals found in Hawaii and status of marine mammals scored based on ESA status.
reference: US Fish and Wildlife Service; NOAA Hawaii marine mammal list

header_layer: ESA seabird and coastal bird status
description: The list of seabirds and coastal birds scored based on ESA status and State of the Birds watch lists.
reference: Costa, Bryan; Kendall, Matthew (2016). Marine Biogeographic Assessment of the Main Hawaiian Islands: Synthesized physical and biological data offshore of the Main Hawaiian Islands from 1891-01-01 to 2015-03-01 (NCEI Accession 0155189). Version 1.1. NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information. Dataset. doi:10.7289/V56H4FG9 May 15, 2017

description: The inverse of the Social Progress Index scores.
The Inverse of World Governance Indicators (WGI) calculated as the six combined scores.
The average number of visitor days by county.

The percent of nearhsore areas priority watersheds protected in reference to Hawaii Stanability Initatives (30 by 30 targets). This data may change as the State DLNR Division of Aquatic Resources develops the 30 by 30 initative.
Visitor generated GDP with a target set by the Hawaii Tourism Authority of 2.5% annual growth.
The Hawaii Tourism Authority's survey on resident sentiment to tourism.
The percent of visitors that report having an excellent experience.
The ratio of watershed partnerships to historic native forest extent.
Wetlands layer clipped to 1km inland from coast. Included only wetlands that are in shallow water and coastal for use in the coastal protection goal
reference: HI wetlands layer (1979) and TNC marxan wetlands layer.

description: The World Governance Indicators (WGI) six combined scores.
